A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: Hello Readers! The Senior Class and the Ninth Grade spent Tuesday on a Field Trip, visiting the Lynch burg Foundry at its Open House. The guided tour of the plant was very educational. Parts are made for big machineryincluding tractors, water pipes and the Long Manufac turing Companys needs. We saw the molten metal being poured into molds made at the foundry welders, drilling engineers, the precision in struments used to measure the finish ed products and the strength of the products. To see approximately 700 workers on the job was also interest ingeach doing his assigned duty. Cooperation and safety were witness ed by us. Mrs. O. W. Smith and Mrs. H. P. James accompanied the fifty students on this trip. Today in Assembly we shall see the installation of Student Council officers and hear Representative Watkins M. Abbitt speak to the en tire student body. The N. F. A. has elected the fol lowing officers President, Joe Robinson Vice-pres., Bobby Booker Secretary, Samuel Scruggs Treasurer, Milton Minnifield Reporter, Herbert Williams Chaplain, Raymond Lawing Song leader, James Williams Historian, Sidney Watts Parliamentarian, William Bruce. The N. H. A. held its regular meeting on Monday in the Home Economics Building. Effie McCoy and Celestine Chambers made a re port of the State Convention which was held at Virginia State College on June 14-17, 1955. The Sixth Grade with Mrs. T. W. Hamlet, Instructor, has begun its second unit of work in social studies on How Early Man Lived and Learned. Many pictures have been collected on early man and much ma terial also. Miss H. B. Stephens reports that 28 students from the Third Grade took the Salk Vaccine shot. This class is progressing nicely in its studies. The Fourth Grade, under Mrs. C. D. Beasley, has been very busy dur ing their Art Period making music books. They enjoyed this activity- very much. Gilbert L. James, Jr., won the first prize for having made the best book. Second prize was won by Dorothy Austin, and Third Prize was won by Augusta McCoy. Each Friday the class looks forward to new activities in the art workbook. The Seventh Grade, under Mrs. T. M. Harris has elected the following officers President, Helen I. Pretson Vice-pres., Jenny M. Burns Secretary, Faye R. Hubbard Asst. Sec., Daisy L. McCoy Treasurer, Margaret Haskins Reporter, Remus A. Mrs. Wilson was born Decembe 14, 1886, the daughter of William Chatham and Martha Jones Abbitt of Appomattox County. Harvey Jesse Harvey, Jr. George Abbitt Terry, Joseph B. Terry, Henry T. Terry, Jr., nephews of Mrs. Wilson, and Buel Harmon. She is also survived by two sis ters, Mrs. Jesse Harvey, of Oak ville and Mrs. H. T. Terry, of Pam plin three brothers, James Curry Abbitt, of Oakville Harry W. Ah bitt, of Wilson, N. C., and G. Owen to arrest Mr. Nowlin, say ing that be had twice shot at her. Heury, a sou of Mr. Nowlin, came up, and went in search of his lather. He found him behind an outhouse. Mr. Nowlin said to him  Get my horse. I want you to carry me to Spout Spring. He spoke so ration ally that the young mau left him to go to the field and take a horse from the plow for bis fathers use in go ing to Spout Spring. Before leav ing his father, Heury tequested him to give up the pistol which he had concealed on his person. Mr. Now lin was searched, but no pistol was found. His son had proceeded ouly a few steps when Mr. Nowlin sent u bullet through his own brain. He eeled aud fell, and died within 30 minutes. The bullet entered his left temple and came out just above his right car. Diligent inquiry has not developed any cause whatever for the rasl. act of Mr. Nowlin, and, al though he was of a despondent dis position and very high-tempered, he had never had an attack that made him the mudmau he was on Friday. Those nearest to him claim that he was evidently cruzy, aud that is the general verdict of the people. He nad for years beeen a great sufferer from ueuralgia and his bodily health was generally rather infirm. Borne reports say that Mr. Nowlin became enraged at a negro servant on the place, and had no occasion to be an gry with his wife, who is one of the best ladies in our county. It is one of the saddest affairs that ever hap pened in this county, as the family upon both sides is well known and highly connected. The deceased was born about 62 years ago in the house in which he was piepared for burial. He was not a member of any church. While he was high-tempered and courageous, he had a warm heart, full of sympathy. He had beeu a merchant and postmaster at Oak ville most of his life, but was engaged in farming at the. time of his death. Besides his wife, who was a Miss Woodson, Mr. Now lin leaves six children. He is also survived by two brothers and two sisters Mr. S. Walker Nowlin, of Lynchburg Mr. William S. Nowlin, of Spout Spring Mrs. Samuel H. Overton, of Spout Spring and Mrs. John Hughes, of Oakville. His burial took place on Saturday even ing, at the family burying ground on the place, and was quite largely attended by friends of the family. Evergreen. We have had another fine rain. The tobacco crop in general is rather small, but is growing well, and nearly every body has a good stand. The corn is looking green and is growing well.
